Key properties of the Lebesgue outer measure include:

fr:ul.fr:li: It is monotone: If E \subseteq F, then m^*(E) \leq m^*(F)
It is countably subadditive: m^*(\cup _{i=1}^{\infty } E_i) \leq \sum _{i=1}^{\infty } m^*(E_i)
It agrees with the standard notion of volume on rectangles
It is translation invariant: m^*(E + x) = m^*(E) for any set E and any x \in \mathbb {R}^n

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The concept of Lebesgue measurability is defined in terms of the Lebesgue outer measure. A set E is Lebesgue measurable if and only if for any set A, m^*(A) = m^*(A \cap E) + m^*(A \setminus E).

Lebesgue measure is the standard way of assigning a measure to subsets of \mathbb {R}^n, generalizing the intuitive notions of length, area, and volume to more complex sets. It is named after Henri Lebesgue.

For "nice" subsets of \mathbb {R}^n (such as intervals in \mathbb {R}, rectangles in \mathbb {R}^2, or rectangular solids in \mathbb {R}^3), the Lebesgue measure coincides with the standard notions of length, area, and volume. However, the Lebesgue measure can also be defined for a wide range of more complex and irregular sets.
Lebesgue measure has several important properties:

fr:ul.fr:li: It is translation invariant: m(E + x) = m(E) for any measurable set E and any x \in \mathbb {R}^n
It is scale invariant: m(\lambda E) = |\lambda |^n m(E) for any measurable set E and any λ \in \mathbb {R}
It is countably additive: If \{E_i\} is a countable collection of pairwise disjoint measurable sets, then m(\cup _i E_i) = \sum _i m(E_i)
It agrees with the standard notion of volume on "elementary sets" (e.g., rectangles)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The construction of Lebesgue measure typically involves defining the Lebesgue outer measure first and then restricting it to the σ-algebra of Lebesgue measurable sets.
A set E in a measure space (X, \mathcal {A}, \mu ) is said to be measurable if it belongs to the σ-algebra \mathcal {A}.

In the context of Lebesgue measure on \mathbb {R}^d, a set is Lebesgue measurable if it belongs to the Lebesgue σ-algebra, which is the σ-algebra generated by all open (or equivalently, closed) subsets of \mathbb {R}^d.
Alternatively, a set E is Lebesgue measurable if for every ε > 0, there exists an open set G containing E such that the Lebesgue outer measure of G \setminus E is less than ε.
